Fields.DialogueText: The Morganas are upon us! Quickly, Men! To your stations.
Worry not, Capitano. We are more than a match for these foul monsters. Do not falter now. I couldn't bear to take orders from someone so weak-willed.
The sentiment is nice but your tongue lashing is as painful as ever. You heard the Belle! Charge!
@BATTLE
Excellent work, Duilio. You've earned a rest.
A rest? This is no time for such things, Capitano. We have emerged victoriously in battle and that is cause for only one thing.

Fields.MenuText: Another battle?

Fields.DialogueText: I may be a battleship but I am not a war-crazed destroyer. Please don't lump me in with such riff-raff, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: A detailed report to our superiors?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Like those stuffed-shirts have any concept of what true combat is like. Best leave them to their own devices and leave the real war to us.

Fields.MenuText: A drink?

Fields.DialogueText: I would prefer to keep the crew's minds untainted by intoxicants. The Morganas are certainly not drowning their days in alcohol and neither should we if we aim to compete.
Then, what do you propose?
A party! It's only natural that the crew should be rewarded for a job well done.
A party?
However, I would like for there to be no alcohol or excessive rambunctiousness at the said party. It will be a civilized celebration of the crew's achievements.
Sounds... riveting...
I think so too. Now, come along, Capitano. You are to help me with the preparations.
Aren't I exempt?
The complete opposite, actually. As the person in charge, you must lead by example. Your happiness should always comes second to your crew's, should it not?
Very well. Lead the way.
I want this party to be equal parts light-hearted and jovial, while at the same time being formal and classy.
I see. It is a little difficult to marry those very... disparate styles.
I'm sure you are up to the task, Capitano. In the meantime, I can begin on meal prep.
Right... I understand the look you are yearning for... I'm just not sure that it's a look that... actually... exists...
*ALARM*
We'll have to continue our discussion later. Please, join me on the battlefield.
@BATTLE
That should keep them at bay for a while. Now, we can return to business.

Fields.MenuText: Have you always held such a stiff upper lip?

Fields.DialogueText: I do not think of myself as some kind of disciplinarian, nor a puritanical saint. I have seen the effect of drink and debauchery on men both aboard ship and in positions of power. It never ends well.

Fields.MenuText: Must we throw a party?

Fields.DialogueText: I do not do this for my sake, Capitano. Those who fight alongside me should take pride in every victory they achieve. Too often does war disillusion men and I never want that to happen.

Fields.MenuText: Why do we need to throw a party?

Fields.DialogueText: I believe I explained briefly before but, in a sense, it is so the men know that we are winning!
With little to no communication with our direct superiors, whether or not a party is being held is the only indication as to whether or not we are moving closer to victory!
I see. Is there anything more I can do to help?
It's fine, Capitano. I'm used to those in positions of power caring little to no regard for the crew's mental wellbeing. That is why I am forced to--
Hang on a minute. Now, I don't know what bad experiences you have had with authority figures in the past but, aboard this ship, I want those serving under me to be as comfortable as possible.
I see. Apologies, Capitano. There was no need for such insolence.
See that it doesn't happen again. Now then, are we permitted to have streamers at this party? What about balloons?
Of course, Capitano! I am no monster. Just refrain from choosing colours that are too bright. We do not want any unwanted stimulation.
Will do.
Yes. Yes. I understand.
Anything to report, Capitano?
I was just informing those back home of our recent victories. They seeemed... less than impressed. I thought it best to avoid telling them about the party for now.
A wise decision.

Fields.MenuText: You feel as if they pry too much as well?

Fields.DialogueText: As if I were a laboratory rat being thrown into deep waters to test a new flotation device. I, nor my crew, will be foddered so easily.

Fields.MenuText: How can we avoid being spied on?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps I shouldn't be telling you this but, a trickle of coffee will temporarily stop any radio from functioning until the liquid dries out.

Fields.MenuText: You're not a fan of such technological advancement?

Fields.DialogueText: Not when it impedes upon my freedom. Don't get me wrong, I love being outfitted with the latest weaponry.
However, I am still partial to a handwritten letter now and again. That feeling of suspense is lost nowadays.
In all honesty, I don't see why I am forced to give such frequent reports. There can only be one of two outcomes. Either, we won or we all perished below the waters.
I may have misjudged you, Capitano. My reflex is always to be wary of those in such authoritative positions but, I believe we could do an ample job of running things without any interferrence.
I think that was a compliment. In which case, thank you.
As I said before, a trickle of coffee is enough to put any radio out of action for at least 24 hours.
What are you proposing?
Nothing at all, Capitano. On a separate note, shall I put the kettle on?
We've received word that Morganas have been running amock in Taranto. Are you familiar with the area?
Somewhat. It's a coastal city in southern Italy home to several historical artifacts. Other than that, I don't know what more information I could provide.
Luckily, I did not take you under my command for your knowledge of small Italian islands.
If Morganas seek to disrupt my homeland, I will do everything in my power to take them down.

Fields.MenuText: Do you hold a personal vendetta against these Morganas?
Are you that patriotic?

Fields.DialogueText: Less of a personal grudge and more of a general one.
No matter who or what it may be; Morgana, invader, or otherwise, I will protect Italy until my dying breath.

Fields.MenuText: Italy was fairly prosperous before the Morgana invasion, was it not?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know if "prosperous" is the right word but we had our heads above water at the very least. The League of Nations will likely use its power to crush us under its thumb at first chance.
I must make sure to gather as many resources as I can from them before that day comes.
*ALARM*
Regardless, we will make haste for Taranto in the morn after a brief stop to gather supplies for the journey ahead. I trust you can take out these Morganas without exhausting our remaining rations?
Leave it to me, Capitano!
@BATTLE
That should do for all the supplies, Capitano. Shall I begin loading them onto the ship?
The battles ahead are going to be long and arduous. Perhaps we should bolster our firepower before continuing onwards.
I believer there is an arms dealer somewhere in this town. I should be able to barter for a good deal as well due to my native heritage.
It would be helpful. We exceeded our budget and then some with food and party supplies.
If you feel it more appropriate to forego the purchasing of any new weapons at this time, I will respect that decision. However, if you choose to pick me up something nice, I will not say no...

Fields.MenuText: With such a lukewarm sentiment, how can I refuse...

Fields.DialogueText: Tepidness is my specialty, after all. Any purchases will be very much appreciated!

Fields.MenuText: You're right. Let's hold off on any expensive items for now.

Fields.DialogueText: And even after my puppy dog routine... I mean, Sì, Capitano!
Several Morganas look to be blocking our exit to the open ocean. Let's take care of them and head straight for Taranto.
Sì, Capitano!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: That's adorable.

Fields.DialogueText: But did it work?
No.
*KABOOM*
*RATATAT*
When you said Taranto was experiencing a "small" infestation, you must forgive me for taking your words literally, Capitano!
I only know what I'm told! I had no idea we'd be ambushed by an entire fleet!
We should be fine. Just make sure you -- AH!
*KABOOM*
Duilio!
I'm hit... we should retreat, Capitano. If we can make it to shallow waters, the crew can conduct the necessary repairs.
You heard the girl! Get us out of here!
@BATTLE
*Cough cough*

Fields.MenuText: Don't push yourself.
Can you deduce where you were hit?
If only we knew to expect an ambush...

Fields.DialogueText: Those who send men to their death on a daily basis must have the ability to erase all notions of guilt from their mind. It is a skill that comes with the job. Necessary, no doubt, but unfortunate.
My head won't stop spinning. I can feel the forward main battery magazines being flooded as we speak, however.
I'll be fine, Capitano... You won't get rid of me that easily...
The crew are doing the best they can while you're aground. We may have to return to Genoa to complete the immediate repairs.
I'm sure the crew will be enough to get me up and running again. I don't like the thought of returning in such a dishevelled state.
... I'll try and keep you out on open waters as best I can. And, until you're fully recovered, I will not leave your side.
Capitano... I'm beginning to regret toying with you so much. You are truly dependable in a crisis.
Thank you, Duilio.
Albeit a little slow on the uptake at times.
Don't ruin the moment.
How does it look, Capitano? Am I for the chopping block?
Don't be so dramatic. The repairs are all finished and we should be able to get back out onto the sea immediately.
Thank you, Capitano. It would be unbecoming for me to return in such an unsightly state.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure no one would lose any respect for you.

Fields.DialogueText: But I would lose respect for myself.

Fields.MenuText: Would you be penalized?

Fields.DialogueText: No but, as I am trying to foster a dynamic in which Belles and their captains can be left unsupervised, it does not help my case to arrive in tatters needing repairs.

Fields.MenuText: Have you ever been injured like this before?

Fields.DialogueText: A magazine explosion wrecked one of my barbette hoists in 1925 and I was out of order until 1928.
I had a lot of time to reflect on things during those 3 years and vowed to never be put in such a position ever again.
We should be ready to head back to sea now. Can you stand?
Perhaps, I could stay seated a little while longer.
Duilio?
It is such a nice day, after all. It would be a shame to squander such good weather by returning inside.
Very well, take all the time you--
Perhaps, you would care to join me. It would be a shame to squander... um...
Very well. Move over.
Thank you, Capitano.
It must be exhausting putting on this tough guy front all the time. Try to let your hair down once in a while. No one will lose any respect for you should you do so.
I'll keep that in mind, Capitano.
*ALARM*
Morganas! Duilio--
Say no more, Capitano. I've been waiting to get back out there! Please, stay behind me!
@BATTLE
What are you polishing there, Duilio?
It's one of several participation trophies. We have a lot of crew members and not all of them see the glory of the battlefield.
So…
Just because the medical practitioner does not weaponize his stethoscopes, does not mean he is not vital to our operation. Every man aboard this ship deserves to have their talents recognized.

Fields.MenuText: That's a very nice thing to do.
Will I be receiving a trophy perchance?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't do it for praise, Capitano. I do it for the sake of morale.
I'm not sure if you've done anything deserving of such a prize, Capitano. If you'd like to put in an application listing all your contributions to the war effort, I would be happy to consider you.

Fields.MenuText: My men are not infants. They do not require their efforts be pasted on the fridge door for all to see.

Fields.DialogueText: Must you be so jaded, Capitano? I am well are that your men require no recognition for completing their duties but does that mean we cannot praise them anyway?
Do people thank you for all you do aboard ship, Duilio?
Thank me? Well, I am often thanked for the presents and parties I provide as thanks to the crew for their efforts. But, for battling Morganas, I require no such praise.
*ALARM*
Speak of the devil. Capitano, with me!
@BATTLE
Capitano, do you have a moment?
For you? Always.
Flattery will get you everywhere, Capitano. Be careful.
What is it you need?
I was wondering if you had seen a large black binder about.
I can't say that I have.
I see. I must have misplaced it. Thank you for your time.

Fields.MenuText: Wait!
Where did you last see it?

Fields.DialogueText: Time is of the essence, Capitano. I am in the throes of a party-planning meltdown, so make it quick.
I believe it was in the mess hall but I cannot be certain. My mind is frazzled thanks to this party.

Fields.MenuText: It isn't like you to misplace things.

Fields.DialogueText: Even corporeal manifestations of a battleship taking the form of an adorable Roman legionary can make mistakes, you know.
What was the book about? Was it a party planning notebook?
No, it was a detailed record of actions committed aboard ship; big and small.
I see, you were planning on excluding the ne'er-do-wells from the party.
I don't believe such a cruel punishment would do well for morale, Capitano. On the contrary, I was checking what duties had been completed and by whom in order to see who would be the most stressed.
And you could cut the said person an extra slice of cake?
Metaphorically speaking, yes.
This record book sounds awfully invasive. I'm a little worried to read my section.
Oh, Capitano. I would never write a section about you. Why would I have the need? You make sure to complete your duties on time as much as possible... don't you?
*ALARM*
Morganas! Maybe they took the record book, Duilio. And if not... perhaps we could feed it to them...
What was that, Capitano?
To battle!
@BATTLE
Thank you for agreeing to dock, Capitano. This party is shaping up to be more of a struggle than I had once thought.
You're telling me. You've already exhausted the supplies we bought before and resorted to stripping down pillow cases for decorations!
I'll be sure to replace everything I take using my own money. However, I wanted to ask for a favor.
I'm all ears.
After I was run aground, I sustained significant damage to my weapons.
I think I see where this is going.
I wouldn't ask for much but, just so I can feel like myself again, would you have the heart to restore me to my former glory? Or better?

Fields.MenuText: When you ask like that, how can I refuse?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm the luckiest Belle in the world.

Fields.MenuText: Those baby-doll eyes aren't going to work every time.

Fields.DialogueText: Understood. I will try and keep my insatiable cuteness in reserve for more pressing negotiations.
It seems we've been followed.
We should put a stop to their patrol before they reach the shoreline. The public are in danger.
Agreed. Let's load up and move out!
Aye, aye, Capitano!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: ... You don't have to sweet-talk me into essential repairs, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I just like staying in practice.
Such crisp air, wouldn't you agree, Capitano?
It certainly is palatable.
Days like these make me long for this war to be over. I would give nothing more than to return to my hometown.

Fields.MenuText: Are you so smitten with Italy?

Fields.DialogueText: Italy will always hold a special place in my heart. I will admit to holding scorn for other countries, especially Greece, but Italy can do no wrong in my eyes. The country that is. Not the people.

Fields.MenuText: Do you feel as though Italy is being led by competent men?

Fields.DialogueText: I have never been a fan of dictatorships. Giulio Cesare, Mussolini... the council surrounding these people sets my heart at ease but I would feel better if the leader's were changed more regularly.

Fields.MenuText: What will you do once the war is over?

Fields.DialogueText: I will return to Italy and rebuild what will inevitably have been destroyed during wartime. Said act will take a lifetime and I cannot think of any other place I would rather grow old.
We must return to Italy together sometime and tour the villas.
I would like that very much. I only worry whether Italy will still be standing at that time. The men in power care only for political advancement and not for the longevity of the country.
That's likely why you were awakened, is it not? With you in the picture, Italy's future looks bright and prosperous.
... I suppose you're right.
Is that a smile, Duilio?
*ALARM*
It must be your imagination, Capitano! I am smiling because I get to fight some Morganas!
So, which is it? My imagination or--
Gah! There is no time for this interrogation! Please join me on the battlefield!
@BATTLE
Is there a particular reason why you asked me here today, Capitano?
I thought you deserved a break. You spend so much time with the crew that it must be overwhelming.
You are an exception, Capitano, but I have always found myself more comfortable amidst the horde of common sailors.

Fields.MenuText: Have you always felt this way?

Fields.DialogueText: As long as I can remember. People in positions of power have had more than one opportunity to win me over but they have tripped at every hurdle.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't think a group of messy sailors would be your cup of tea.

Fields.DialogueText: It's true I often feel myself acting as the disciplinarian of the group but I share most of the same morales and ideals as sailors. As opposed to my superiors at least.

Fields.MenuText: I'm an exception?

Fields.DialogueText: It's strange. Despite your position, you have more in common with the beer swilling, drunkard, layabouts you keep in your employ. I truly respect that about you.
Gee, thanks...
*ALARM*
Morganas!
Quickly, Captain! We must make haste!
@BATTLE
We're under siege!
@BATTLE
Job well done, Capitano. I believe my preparations for the party are finished now as well.
It only bankrupted the both of us...
I trust you will be joining us for some light refreshments and chit-chat?

Fields.MenuText: A captain should not fraternize with those of lower rank.

Fields.DialogueText: Normally, I would wholeheartedly agree, Capitano. However, you display such a penchant for peasant-style morality I think you would fit in just perfectly.

Fields.MenuText: A party with no alcohol? Pass.

Fields.DialogueText: If you need alcohol to enjoy things, Capitano, you shouldn't have it at all. I can make you a nice cup of coffee instead?

Fields.MenuText: I don't think I have much to discuss with the crew aside from scolding them for their negligence.

Fields.DialogueText: Then feel free to stay by my side as that was my primary goal for the evening as well!
The more we discuss my inclusion, the less I believe myself to have a choice.
It seems you are more quick-witted than I thought, Capitano. Here, take my hand.
What's this--
I know it can be daunting to attend a social gathering where you know no one at the event.
I know my--
You know these men as your loyal crew. However, I'm sure you know very little of their personal lives and interpersonal relationships.
That is true... It may be awkward for me to try and intrude on these prior friendships.
We will go together. I'm sure you have no qualms about an evening spent in my company, do you?
Even if I did, I would know better to keep my mouth shut.
Eccellente!
How was that, Capitano?
You know, for a night of relative docility, I had a lot of fun.
I knew you would. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy a glass of wine now and again too. I just think there is a time and a place for it.

Fields.MenuText: What time and or place would that be?

Fields.DialogueText: During a ceasefire? A wedding night? Any occassion that does not require one to sober up instantly should a bomb suddenly be dropped on their head.

Fields.MenuText: You favor wine?

Fields.DialogueText: Is that so surprising? Italian wine is some of the finest this side of the world.

Fields.MenuText: Alcohol can be disruptive...

Fields.DialogueText: The worst decisions are made in a state of intoxication. It leads to debauchery and primal instincts which have no place in a combat situation where those who are sober are risking their lives.
I've been saving this for a special occassion. Now seems as good a time as any.
It looks delicious, Capitano, but...
*ALARM*
We'll clear out the area of Morganas and return for a single drink. Sound fair?
If you insist.
@BATTLE
Who knew you were such a lightweight, Duilio?
Please stop talking, Capitano... My head feels as thought it is about to burst.
What happened last night? After I finished the glass, I have little to no recollection.
Oh, don't you worry. I'll be sure to let you know just as soon as I need something from you.
Speaking of which, Capitano. I am sure a senior Belle I know of told me that the cure for any hangover is a new set of weaponry?
I see. For humans, it's a bloody mary. For Belles, it's a bomber!
I would be most grateful if you would relieve me from this hell.
You reap what you sow, Duilio.
I believe YOU were the one who forced such poison upon me. And now you will not take responsibility for your actions. How cruel you can be at times, Capitano.
Several Morganas look to be making their approach. Duilio, are you functional?
Let's just take things slowly, please. We may need to employ one or two more cleaners should this jostling continue... A Belle feeling seasick... How embarrassing...
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I was under the impression Belles were essentially immune to hangovers.

Fields.DialogueText: So was I!

Fields.MenuText: Shall I see if I can find you some kind of pick-me-up?

Fields.DialogueText: Find me anything that could work, please.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry.

Fields.DialogueText: What's that you've got there, Duilio? More participation trophies?
Not exactly. These are the same participation trophies you know and love. These are medals I plan to give out to those who display exceptional bravery in battle.
Is that so?
Sì. And these are pin badges awarded to those I deem particularly hard-workers.
Is there a reason you're polishing these awards so fervently as oppose to... I don't know... awarding them to the people?
I thought it would be nice to make a display case and hang it in the mess hall.

Fields.MenuText: Decorative and motivational. I like it.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly. The crew can track their progress with the incentive to earn more medals than their fellow man.

Fields.MenuText: Are you okay with fostering a racehorse mentality in the men?

Fields.DialogueText: At the end of the day, all that matters is results. Whether the men are fighting for their homeland, fighting for their wives, or fighting for a shiny medal, as long as we win, I can sleep easy.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't know you were so handy.

Fields.DialogueText: You underestimate me, Capitano. I built and attached this ship's corvus all by myself, thank you very much.
Make sure you hang it up properly. You know just how much turbulence we experience on a daily basis.
I'll be sure to make the proper fittings and use a shatter resistant glass. Even a Morgana's cannon fire could not penetrate it!
*ALARM*
What say we put that to the test?
I'd be happy to!
@BATTLE
We're under attack!
@BATTLE
I'm exhausted.
I think it's time we had another party. I will begin the preparations immediately.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure about that?

Fields.DialogueText: Why ever not?

Fields.MenuText: Remember what happened last time?

Fields.DialogueText: No! I don't! That's the problem! You are insistent that I performed some kind of embarrassing act while intoxicated but refuse to tell me what it is! It's incredibly infuriating!

Fields.MenuText: Another party?

Fields.DialogueText: Are you averse to fun, Capitano?
What if we tried a different kind of event. Something a little different than a party?
Do you have any suggestions?
I'm just the idea machine. You're the creator here.
Hmm. I will admit, you have sparked my interest.
That's what I'm here for.
Leave it with me and I will let you know if I come up with anything.
How goes the pondering, Duilio? Have you struck gold yet?
Not yet, Capitano. However, I find standing out here and staring into the horizon helps clear my head from distractions.

Fields.MenuText: Something on your mind?

Fields.DialogueText: There is always something I should be doing. I rarely have a moment to myself and, even when I do, I am expected to document it and file a report to my superiors.

Fields.MenuText: Can I help alleviate some of the stress?

Fields.DialogueText: What exactly are you proposing, Capitano? I would love a foot massage if you are offering.

Fields.MenuText: The ocean breeze is really calming.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, I know you share the same love of the sea that I do.
Do you spy that in the distance?
Morganas, it seems.
The lookout seems to be preoccupied. I'll sound the alarm.
Actually, Capitano, I will take care of these monsters myself. No need to alert the crew.
Duilio?
Only that, it is such a peaceful day, I would hate to ruin it with the blaring of unnecessary sirens.
Will you be all right by yourself?
Who are you talking to?
@BATTLE
And then it came to me, as if sent from the heavens above! The perfect substitute for a large party!
And that is?
*ALARM*
Best we take care of the Morganas first, Capitano. I want your undivided attention!
@BATTLE
An awards ceremony!
I'm not following.
What better event is there to combine my love of symbolic gifts with stress-relieving events! An awards ceremony to honor the special crew aboard ship!

Fields.MenuText: And what about those positively unspectacular?

Fields.DialogueText: Everyone will receive something, Capitano! No one will go home empty-handed.

Fields.MenuText: Will this be a formal event like your parties?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course there will be no alcohol or excessive debauchery. However, I in no way expect the crew to arrive in black-tie.

Fields.MenuText: How will it work?

Fields.DialogueText: I will create categories like "bravest crewman" or "most helpful during downtime" and bestow a plethora of awards to those who come out on top based on an anonymous voting system!
I see. So we will vote in specific categories that you create to determine the victor for each award.
Exactly!
That sounds like it could be a lot of fun.
I'm glad you approve, Capitano, as that brings me to my next favor.
Which is?
There is a port up ahead. I'm sure you know where I'm going with this.
I certainly do but I fear my poor wallet cannot take much more of your excessive spending...
This should suffice, Capitano. Thank you for all your help.
Just how many trophies and medals do we need for this ceremony?
What a redundant question! How would you feel if you were the only person not to receive an award at such a prestigious event. Everyone needs to place first in at least one category.
We have how many men aboard ship? These categories are going to become relatively niche as time goes on.
I don't think so, Capitano. My record book keeps track of everyone's actions aboard ship. Everyone plays their part and excels in at least on faculty.
I see. I never knew I had employed such studious men.
You have great taste, Capitano. Although, "best at cleaning the latrines" may have to make an appearance at some time or another.
Is that all for today?
I'd hoped that, through this ceremony, we could bolster the confidence of the men. I'm sure they'll all be in veritable moods after the ceremony.
I don't doubt it.
My desire is that they will learn from each other and seek out the teachings of the first place finishers.
It's a good strategy.
Perhaps now would be a good time to add to our ranks. With everyone in such a spirited mood, enthusiastic to impart their wisdom, it would make training new recruits much less taxing on your end.

Fields.MenuText: Anything to relieve the pressure on my end.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll put in a word at the nearby academy that we are looking for men yet to find their sea legs.

Fields.MenuText: I think we'll be fine with the men at hand.

Fields.DialogueText: As do I, it was only a suggestion.
Come now. Let's clear out any Morganas waiting for us by the ship and head back out to sea. I'm sure there is a lot of preparation that still needs to be done on your end.
Right you are!
@BATTLE
Thank you all for joining me today for this, the first annual Duilio-hosted awards ceremony!
*CHEERING*
Now, before we begin, our Capitano would like to say a few words.
Thank you, Duilio.
Capitano; the floor is yours.

Fields.MenuText: Let's all give Duilio a big hand for organizing this event!

Fields.DialogueText: Capitano... everyone... Honestly, there is no need... This is your day so please enjoy it!

Fields.MenuText: I don't want to see any excessive floundering in the crowd during the performance.

Fields.DialogueText: As strict as ever, Capitano! Although, i will have to second this motion!

Fields.MenuText: Please seek out those who win awards and learn from them.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, if you struggle to efficiently load cannonballs, please seek the knowledge from the first place cannonball loader!
*ALARM*
Voting is still underway so anyone who wants to win the "most Morganas bested in a single fight" award, better get out there now!
*CHEERING*
@BATTLE
Now then, we're winding down here. Did everybody have a good time?
*CHEERING*
There is one final award left to give. Capitano, would you please come to the stage!

Fields.MenuText: Shouldn't you announce the category first before the winner? This is a little anticlimactic...

Fields.DialogueText: It can't be helped as you are the only one yet to receive an award!

Fields.MenuText: I thought for sure I would win best dressed. This naval uniform was custom-made!

Fields.DialogueText: Unfortunately, one of the crew members' father is a professional tailor!

Fields.MenuText: Let's make this quick and return to business.

Fields.DialogueText: As stoic as ever! Unfortunately, there is no award for the biggest spoil-sport!
*ALARM*
Morganas! Let's deal with them quickly before returning.
Keeping the audience in suspense... I like your style, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Very well, what award have I won?
There was one category where only yourself could be chosen as the victor.

Fields.MenuText: So, I won by default?

Fields.DialogueText: We all agreed that no one else was deserving of even being considered for this award.

Fields.MenuText: People were forced to choose me?

Fields.DialogueText: I wouldn't say forced. This ship is not and will never be a dictatorship.

Fields.MenuText: I was only nominated for one category?

Fields.DialogueText: I felt it unfair to have you as a nominee for Morgana kills or battles won as you would place first every time!
Let me hear it.
And the award for "most likely to bring about an end to this war" goes to... Capitano!
*CHEERING*
Excuse me?
We all agreed that, regardless of our personal efforts, without you behind the wheel, we would never get anywhere. We're all behind you, Capitano. Every step of the way.
Thank you, everyone. It means a lot to me.
*ALARM*
Now, show me that you earned those awards!
@BATTLE
That about wraps things up, wouldn't you say, Capitano?
Not quite. Here, take this.
What's this?
A medal of honor. "For outstanding excellence in the field of brilliance."
I see, this is an award for a child.
I'm not good at names and I wanted to keep things vague considering you do so much aboard ship.
Capitano...

Fields.MenuText: You did not allow yourself to take part in the ceremony so...

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, the ceremony was not for me. Still... this is...

Fields.MenuText: I just wanted to let you know that you matter just as much as the crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitano... You're going to make me blush...

Fields.MenuText: The name could use a little work, I'll admit.

Fields.DialogueText: No, no. Ignore my reflexive sarcasm. I love it.
*ALARM*
Morganas. Capitano, might I have a word with you after dispatching these monsters?
By all means. My office doors are always open.
@BATTLE
You wanted to speak with me, Duilio?
I did.
*ALARM*
Allow me to dispatch of these Morganas first, Capitano. I want your full attention.
@BATTLE
As you know, Capitano, the crew will always come first in my heart.

Fields.MenuText: They mean a lot to you.

Fields.DialogueText: We share a lot of the same ideals yet these men are treated as disposable by those in power. I will never look on them in such a way.

Fields.MenuText: You've had bad experiences with those in power, I know.
That is why you are so stern with them.

Fields.DialogueText: Like a parent steering their child away from drink and debauchery, I must do the same for the crew's safety.
They see the crew as fodder. I cannot respect such people.
What does that have to do with me?
I worried a lot about joining your regiment. I struggle to respect those with seniority over myself and prefer to be left to my own devices without being constantly surveyed.
I see.
But you, Capitano... You have opened my eyes to a world in which the leaders of tomorrow have compassion for their subordinates.
As any upstanding person should have.
You also respect my constant partying and sly jabs on your personality without reprimanding me too harshly.
I know you are joking, after all.
For all of these things and more, I will happily follow you until this war ends and even after that. If you'll have me, of course.

Fields.MenuText: I couldn't think of someone I'd rather have by my side.
I too cannot envision a world in which we are not together.

Fields.DialogueText: What say we sail off into the sunset, Capitano?
I'd like that very much.
And after the war ends...?
I will stay by your side until my dying breath.
